1.text: Today's video is an altered art project

4.text: and for this, I am altering a Yankee Candle reed diffuser bottle.

7.text: To begin with I'm going to create a textured surface on the bottle

14.text: so I've torn up some tissue paper

16.text: and I'm going to adhere that to the bottle using Golden's Soft Gel Medium.

19.text: I've chosen a soft gel as it's stronger than a fluid matt medium

23.text: and although it's not as strong as a regular gel,

26.text: the soft gel's not as thick, so it's easier to work with,

30.text: So there's the bottle totally covered

34.text: and I also decided to add some of this decorative tissue paper

39.text: just to add a little bit of interest.

41.text: A lot of this does get covered up eventually,

43.text: but I wasn't too sure at this stage how much would get covered up

47.text: so I wanted to make sure there was something of interest other than the plain tissue on the bottle

68.text: Now I'm going to add some colour to the bottle

72.text: and for this, I've selected Silks Acrylic Glazes

76.text: in four different colours, although I actually only end up using 3 of these colours,

80.text: the two blues and the lime green

82.text: And I've chosen glazes because of their transparent nature

85.text: so you are going to be able to see the pattern on that music paper

89.text: The first colour that I'm covering the bottle completely with is the lighter blue.

118.text: And the second colour I'm using here is the darker blue

131.text: And finally, this is the Key Lime

134.text: And then I go back with each of the colours again and just blend them through

146.text: This is Pearlescent White by Lumiere

149.text: and I'm using this to add some softness to the piece

153.text: and to bring some highlights to it

179.text: Now I want to age the bottle

181.text: So I'm using Basics, Raw Umber

183.text: And, this looks quite dramatic at first

185.text: painting a layer of watered down paint all over the bottle

188.text: But as you can see, I'm wiping most of it off with a baby wipe

193.text: So that the dark brown colour

195.text: Is only left in the crevices of the texture

218.text: The next thing I want to do is create some embellishments for the bottle

223.text: so I'm using Premo by Sculpey

230.text: And I show the process of putting the clay into the mould

234.text: I have been asked about this before

235.text: So I tend to put a piece, a little oversized into the mould

239.text: squeeze it in as much as I can, and then

242.text: use a flexible blade to shave off the excess

245.text: until it's flush with the top of the mould

249.text: And then I usually put it into the fridge for a little while

252.text: and that makes it easier to take it out

256.text: Then once they've been taken out of the mould,

259.text: I bake them on a ceramic tile

261.text: for about 15 minutes for little pieces like this

264.text: and here they are, once they've been taken out

277.text: Now I'm going to add some colour to the pieces

281.text: I've chosen two Liquitex Basics paints

287.text: and I add two coats of the paint

291.text: Although you actually only see me apply one coat here

296.text: The first coat tends to seep into the clay

301.text: because clay is a porous surface

302.text: so that's the reason for adding two coats

305.text: and I'm just using a detail brush by Art Master

309.text: and a pair of tweezers to hold them

312.text: since they are particularly small and fiddly pieces

315.text: and they do want to move around a great deal

370.text: And once the flowers have been painted

373.text: I start to paint the little hummingbirds

376.text: four humingbirds in total for this project

379.text: so I'm just going to show you one of them

382.text: This again, is Liquitex basics paint

385.text: in Light Green Permanent to begin with

396.text: And now I'm going back to the crimson colour

399.text: the same crimson that I used on the flowers

407.text: Pearlescent white that I used on the bottle

409.text: at the very start of the video

412.text: And this is Lumiere Halo Blue Gold

416.text: and this is so I can add that irridescence that hummingbirds have to their wings

423.text: And you'll also notice that the hummingbird's beak and eye have been coloured

429.text: with some black which I did off camera

453.text: And whilst I'm waiting for those clay pieces to dry

456.text: I'm taking some Junkyard Findings by Prima

459.text: These are the Rose Heart Corners

463.text: and I'm going to paint these with the Lumiere Pearlescent White

467.text: to match other elements of the project

496.text: This is Brilliant Yellow Green from Basics

501.text: from the same mould as the flowers and hummingbirds

506.text: and just like those elements they're getting two coats of this paint

517.text: And now back to the Prima pieces

519.text: and I'm aging these in the same way that I did the bottle at the start of the video

525.text: So I've just applied a layer of brown paint

530.text: brushing it into all the crevices

532.text: and then dabbing it off with a baby wipe

536.text: so that it is only left in some areas

538.text: And I apply the same aging technique to all the clay elements in the project

551.text: Now I'm using Glossy Accents by Ranger

554.text: to adhere the Prima pieces down

559.text: over something like a hot glue because

562.text: you have time to manipulate the pieces before it dries

571.text: and I'm just adding a little bit of the Lumiere paint

575.text: to darken them a little bit

598.text: Now, I decide to add some of the Brilliant Yellow Green

601.text: onto the leaves of the Prima pieces

605.text: So that's what you can see me doing here

608.text: and again, I add two coats of this paint

630.text: Next, I'm using Ranger Glossy Accents again

633.text: to adhere the little clay embellishments that I've made

635.text: onto the bottle and form my design

723.text: Once the Glossy Accents has had time to set

726.text: I'm going back to the Silks Paints

730.text: and I'm going to start to add some shadows

736.text: So, as I say, I'm starting off here with the Majestic Blue

740.text: which was the darkest of the two blues

743.text: I used at the start of the project on the bottle

745.text: Then, later on, I use Golden's Fluid Acrylic in Payne's Grey

750.text: just to add the very darkest areas of shadow

847.text: Now that the front of the bottle is complete

850.text: I'm going to work on a design on the back of the bottle

853.text: So, I'm using the same elements as before

859.text: and also the clay embellishments that I made from the mould

1034.text: Now I have both sides of the bottle complete

1037.text: with the clay embellishments and design

1040.text: I decided to add a border

1043.text: or frame, around the sides of the bottle

1087.text: Now I'm adding some of the clay flowers and leaves to the sides of the bottle

1092.text: so that no matter what angle you are viewing the bottle

1097.text: there will be some area of interest

1128.text: For the final part of the project

1131.text: I'm adding some fibres around the neck of the bottle

1133.text: in shades of blue that compliment the rest of the project

1153.text: And here is the finished bottle

1155.text: I hope you enjoyed watching the process as much as I did creating it

1161.text: There'll be a link to the full materials list in the video description

1167.text: you'll find both the link to the project materials

1170.text: as well as my social media links

1172.text: so if you wanted to follow me

1174.text: on my blog or Ustream, Facebook or Twitter

1180.text: So until next time, thanks for watching and have a great day!
